entities: Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1540 (2004)
summary:
The Security Council, Resolving to seek a safer world for all and to create conditions for a world without nuclear weapons, in accordance with the Treaty on Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) goals, promoting international stability, and based on undiminished security for all. 

Reaffirming the Statement of its President (S/23500) on 31 January 1992, including the need for all Member States to fulfil obligations on arms control, disarmament, and prevent proliferation of all weapons of mass destruction.

Reaffirming proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and their means of delivery constitutes a threat to international peace and security.

Bearing in mind responsibilities of other UN organs and international organizations in disarmament, arms control, and non-proliferation.

Underlining the NPT as the cornerstone of the nuclear non-proliferation regime and essential foundation for nuclear disarmament and peaceful uses of nuclear energy.

Reaffirming commitment to the NPT, conviction that the international nuclear non-proliferation regime should be maintained and strengthened.

Calling for further progress on all aspects of disarmament to enhance global security.

Recalling previous resolutions and statements, including (S/PRST/2008/43).

Welcoming decisions of non-nuclear-weapon States that have dismantled their nuclear programs or renounced nuclear weapons.

Welcoming nuclear arms reduction efforts by nuclear-weapon States, and underlining the need for further efforts in nuclear disarmament.

Welcoming the Russian Federation and US decision to negotiate a new comprehensive agreement to replace the Treaty on Reduction and Limitation of Strategic Offensive Arms.

Supporting the establishment of nuclear-weapon-free zones, and the Second Conference of States Parties and signatories.

Reaffirming resolutions 825 (1993), 1695 (2006), 1718 (2006), 1874 (2009), and other non-proliferation resolutions.

Gravely concerned about nuclear terrorism, recognizing the need for all States to prevent nuclear material or technical assistance becoming available to terrorists.

Noting with interest the initiative to convene an international conference on peaceful uses of nuclear energy.

Expressing support for the 2010 Global Summit on Nuclear Security.

Affirming support for the Convention on Physical Protection of Nuclear Material and its 2005 Amendment, and the Convention for the Suppression of Acts of Nuclear Terrorism.
